awd_titl_txt: LUCID: A Spectator Targeted Visualization System to Broaden Participation at Cyber Defense Competitions
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to stimulate interest in cybersecurity competitions through the development of a visualization and broadcast system targeted to enhancing learning and understanding among spectators. The system engages the spectator by presenting information pertinent to understanding the real-time details of the game in a usable and spirited manner. It accomplishes this through the combination of various techniques, including real-time network security visualization, live video and audio monitoring, animation, computer graphics and commentary. As a result, the project improves the educational value and excitement for the spectator and broaden interest in the field of cybersecurity. 

The proposed tool captures computer and network activities for all the competing teams and present them in a user-friendly manner for the benefit of the spectator using state-of-the-art broadcasting, animation and commentary. Although visualization has been utilized at large-scale cyber defense competition, such as the Mid-Atlantic Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition, it is still used only in a limited way. Further, it does not target the spectator in a serious way and it is rarely used for small-scale cyber defense competitions, which is the main target of this project. 

By improving the spectator experience, more students are attracted to collegiate cyber defense competitions and ultimately to cyber security related fields. The tool is also beneficial to competition participants, especially to student teams who could use the tool for network security visualization.

por.por_cntn:
In a cyber defense competition, teams of students are charged with managing and defending an enterprise network against security attacks from a team of experienced hackers. The stated purpose of these competitions is education, and the goal is to help students better defend computer systems and networks against attacks. However, the number of student participants engaged in these competitions has remained relatively small, especially among underrepresented minorities. One of the reasons for this lack of interest may be attributed to the fact that, to date, the competitions have been beneficial mainly to participants?student teams, judges, administrators, etc. However, for a spectator of the sport, the excitement and educational value do not necessarily transfer. We hypothesize that this is mainly due to the challenge associated with the spectator's ability to extract, visualize and comprehend the details of the game as it transpires in real-time. Further, by improving this spectator experience, more students would be attracted to collegiate cyber defense competitions and ultimately to cybersecurity-related fields.

This project aims to stimulate interest in cybersecurity competitions by developing a visualization and broadcast system targeted to enhance learning and understanding among spectators. To support this goal, we have designed LUCID, a comprehensive visualization software application for cyber security visualization and commentary. The application consists of five component types: components for monitoring network traffic, components for reporting various network messages, data storage components, and a visualization component. Additionally, it has an automated animation reporting component. LUCID can serve as an aid in teaching complex concepts in cybersecurity in the classroom or to visually demonstrate active security events on a network to an audience (or to participants) in a cyber-defense competition in near real-time. LUCID's flexibility enables it to visualize different cybersecurity concepts, protocols, and ideas. The system aims to improve sense-making for a cyber defense competition audience, more precisely, novice and intermediate members of such an audience. Fig 1 shows the visualization of the three network services currently supported by LUCID--MySQL, secure shell (SSH), and network time protocol (NTP).

Motivated by the effectiveness of video games in education, the animated commentator subsystem uses a game-like framework to help non-expert audiences comprehend the concepts and engage them in cybersecurity-related events. It seeks to promote cybersecurity education and awareness among non-expert audiences. Specifically, the commentator can: (1) perform a variety of human-like behaviors, ranging from various valenced facial expressions, gestures, gaze and emotions conveyed in speech, (2) interact with audiences, and provide several types of feedback, including causal, congratulatory, deleterious, assistive, background, and motivational responses, and (3) provide visual cues when producing speech, using the lips, tongue, and jaw, which complement auditory cues. In addition, the virtual commentator is flexible enough to be employed in the Collegiate Cyber Defense Competitions (CCDC) environment. Fig 2 shows the Animated virtual commentator subsystem interface.

Results from subject testing show that LUCID with the embodied virtual commentator provided an engaging environment to improve participants' understanding and sense-making of active security events. More information about this project is available at https://www.ccet-lucid.com/ website.
